item.title: Robert Duvall Seared Himself Into Our Memories Even When He Wasn’t the Star
item.description: In roles as unalike as a neighborhood shut-in, a Corleone consigliere and a hardhearted military man, the actor brought an intensity that never wavered.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.media:description: Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen in “The Godfather Part II.”

item.title: Daniel Radcliffe on Returning to Broadway in ‘Every Brilliant Thing’
item.description: The Tony winner returns to the stage in “Every Brilliant Thing,” an interactive monologue with a message of hope “that might be vital for somebody to hear.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson and Lucia Bell-Epstein
item.media:description: “There’s a lot about this character that I relate to, both in the way that sadness hits them, and in the way that they find joy,” Radcliffe said.

item.title: Frederick Wiseman Watched People Like Nobody Else
item.description: For more than 50 years, the influential documentarian found inspiration in filming the ways his ordinary subjects lived their lives.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.media:description: Frederick Wiseman’s direct cinema style and sharp observations made him a near-peerless documentary filmmaker.

item.title: When Jesse Jackson Came to ‘Sesame Street’: ‘I Am! Somebody!’
item.description: His memorable appearance was brought to us by the letter ‘I,’ for inspiration.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.media:description: Jesse Jackson, right, in a 1972 episode of “Sesame Street,” in which he encouraged children to assert their dignity as human beings, however small they were.

item.title: At 85, the Choreographer Lucinda Childs Still Has a Full Dance Card
item.description: The choreographer has a busy spring: early works at the Guggenheim’s swirling rotunda, a new appointment at Gibney Dance and a robust program at Bard.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas and Heather Sten
item.media:credit: Heather Sten for The New York Times

item.title: Robert Duvall Didn’t Mind Clashing With Directors
item.description: The actor had very particular thoughts on how he should — and shouldn’t — be directed, and he was happy to share them.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Robert Duvall believed a less-is-more philosophy applied to film directing.

item.title: The Opera ‘Monster’s Paradise’ Takes Satirical Aim at Trump
item.description: “Monster’s Paradise,” by Olga Neuwirth and Elfriede Jelinek, attempts an operatic response to current events and politics. Is that possible?
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: The 19-Year Debate over Whether a Painting Was Looted by the Nazis.
item.description: The fuzzy provenance of a Franz Marc masterwork once owned by a Jewish banker, but now held by a German museum, has fueled a lengthy dispute over its ownership.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Hickley

item.title: Shia LaBeouf Charged With Battery in New Orleans
item.description: The actor, known for his roles in “Transformers” and “Megalopolis,” was arrested early Tuesday after reportedly assaulting two people, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A representative for Shia LaBeouf did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Tuesday.

item.title: Kaija Saariaho’s Masterpiece ‘Innocence’ Heads to Met Opera
item.description: Kaija Saariaho’s “Innocence” was celebrated at its premiere. After her death in 2023, her collaborators continue to travel with it around the world.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The composer Kaija Saariaho at Lincoln Center in 2018.

item.title: André De Shields and Junior LaBeija Team Up for ‘Cats: The Jellicle Ball’
item.description: Fifty years ago, Junior LaBeija couldn’t afford to see André De Shields in “The Wiz.” Now, they’re starring together in a reimagining of “Cats.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli and Marcus Maddox
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times

item.title: Kathleen Chalfant and Elizabeth Marvel Are Sobriety Sisters in ‘The Dinosaurs’
item.description: Kathleen Chalfant, Elizabeth Marvel, April Matthis and other actors deliver top-notch performances in a play that leaves questions unanswered.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: From left, Mallory Portnoy, Maria Elena Ramirez and Elizabeth Marvel in “The Dinosaurs” at Playwrights Horizons in Manhattan.

item.title: Peeking Behind the Scenes of ‘Wallace and Gromit’
item.description: An exhibition at the Young V&A in London reveals the painstaking and devoted practice of the characters’ creators, Aardman Studios.
item.dc:creator: Emily LaBarge
item.media:description: A set model from “Wallace and Gromit: Vengeance Most Fowl,” at the exhibition “Inside Aardman: Wallace and Gromit and Friends” at the Young V&A museum in London.

item.title: Romeo Is a Dead Man Would Make Kafka and Lynch Proud
item.description: Romeo Is a Dead Man features a Shakespeare-hating shape-shifter and plenty of zombies.
item.dc:creator: Harold Goldberg
item.category: Romeo Is a Dead Man (Video Game)

item.title: Readers Respond: 11 (More) Transcendent Beatles Covers by Black Musicians
item.description: Thirteen tracks were just the start. Listen to interpretations of the Fab Four via Luther Vandross, Ella Fitzgerald, Sylvester and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:description: Luther Vandross.

item.title: Colbert Doesn’t Give an F.C.C. About Calling Out CBS
item.description: “And because my network clearly doesn’t want us to talk about this, let’s talk about this,” Stephen Colbert said after CBS canceled a Texas state representative’s appearance on Monday’s “Late Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Last Week Tonight With John Oliver (TV Program)
Real Time With Bill Maher (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Shoresy’ Is Back, a Hockey Sitcom With ‘Heated Rivalry’ Ties
item.description: If you want more Canadian TV series about emotionally complex hockey players, look no further.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: Jared Keeso in a scene from Season 5 of “Shoresy.”

item.title: Robert Duvall: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The actor, who had a knack for embodying a wealth of varied characters, had a sprawling and celebrated career.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: Frederick Wiseman, 96, Penetrating Documentarian of Institutions, Dies
item.description: He exposed abuses in films like “Titicut Follies,” a once-banned portrait of a mental hospital, but ranged widely in subject matter, from a Queens neighborhood to a French restaurant.
item.dc:creator: John Anderson
item.media:description: Mr. Wiseman in an undated photo. “I don’t know if I can offer a general definition of what I’m doing,” he said in 2011, “except to say I’m trying to create dramatic structures out of ordinary experience.”

item.title: Where to Watch Robert Duvall’s Top Performances
item.description: He played rugged, capable men drawn from America’s past, present and possible future.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: In “The Godfather,” Robert Duvall played a lawyer advising a band of Italians who respect his counsel but don’t consider him a trusted insider.

item.title: Robert Duvall, ‘Godfather’ and ‘Apocalypse Now’ Actor, Dies at 95
item.description: An Oscar winner, he was known for disappearing into wide-ranging roles in movies like “Apocalypse Now” and “The Godfather” and in the television series “Lonesome Dove.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde Haberman
item.media:description: In a long and varied career, Robert Duvall was nominated for seven Academy Awards for acting, and won once.

item.title: ‘Tragedy of Coriolanus’ Swerves Off Course in Brooklyn
item.description: Theater for a New Audience’s reimagining of the Shakespearean tragedy misses an opportunity to engage the play’s many echoes with our own tense era.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.media:description: Mickey Sumner, left, as Aufidius and McKinley Belcher III as Coriolanus in this Theater for a New Audience production at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

item.title: Ticket Scam Cost the Louvre $12 Million, Investigators Say
item.description: The Paris prosecutor’s office said a network involving museum employees and tour guides had been operating for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators said the suspected scam at the Louvre museum in Paris involved tour guides reusing tickets for different people.

item.title: Henrike Naumann, Artist Set to Represent Germany at Venice Biennale, Dies at 41
item.description: Her death from cancer was the second sudden loss for this year’s edition. Naumann’s exhibition will still go ahead in May, according to a statement.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Henrike Naumann, who was born in East Germany, became known for installations featuring household items that reflect historical and political events.

item.title: Why an A.I. Video of Tom Cruise Battling Brad Pitt Spooked Hollywood
item.description: A 15-second clip created by an artificial intelligence tool owned by the Chinese technology company ByteDance appears more cinematic than anything so far.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Brad Pitt, left, and Tom Cruise at the London premiere of “F1: The Movie” last year. Their images were used in a widely circulated video created with A.I. by the Irish director Ruairi Robinson last week.

item.title: From One President to Another, a Love Letter With an Edge
item.description: To open a series of essays about U.S. presidents, George W. Bush pays tribute to George Washington, who “ensured America wouldn’t become a monarchy, or worse.”
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:description: George W. Bush focuses on the humility of the first president in his essay. Barack Obama is writing about Abraham Lincoln, and Bill Clinton about Theodore Roosevelt.

item.title: Shedding Light on a Roma Artist, and the Fate of Her People
item.description: Ceija Stojka, who made visible the historical injustices to the Roma people during and after the Holocaust, is the subject of a stirring show at the Drawing Center.
item.dc:creator: Aruna D’Souza

item.title: ‘Muppet Treasure Island’ at 30: Tim Curry on His Pirate Role
item.description: A look back at one of the most ambitious Muppets projects, a Robert Louis Stevenson adaptation that turns 30 this month.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar

item.title: What Can Musical Variations Teach Us About Creativity?
item.description: Anthony Brandt, a musicologist whose work focuses on music cognition, talks about what this musical form and how human beings approach open-ended problems.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
item.category: The People United Will Never Be Defeated! (Musical Work)

item.title: Who’s Pulling the Strings on the World Stage? Ask the Puppets.
item.description: Eurasia Group, the geopolitical risk consultancy run by Ian Bremmer, gets into the political satire game with its Instagram show “Puppet Regime.”
item.dc:creator: Kim Córdova
item.category: Reema bint Bandar bin Sultan, Princess of Saudi Arabia

item.title: ‘Star Search,’ Plus 7 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The finale of Netflix’s newest talent competition airs, and the second season of “The Last Thing He Told Me” premieres.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fidelman

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: ‘Get Up!’
item.description: Duncan takes a serious beating. Egg doesn’t like how things are looking.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)
item.media:description: Egg (Dexter Sol Ansell) had good reason to look worried.

item.title: Rosamund Pike in ‘Inter Alia’ and More Theater to Stream
item.description: Other picks include Leo McGann’s thriller “The Honey Trap” for Irish Rep; Anne Gridley’s “Watch Me Walk”; and a Jodi Picoult stage adaptation.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sherman

item.title: ‘The Simpsons’ Hits Another Milestone
item.description: On Sunday the series, the longest running American sitcom, will air its 800th episode on Fox. In an interview, the creator Matt Groening says there’s no end in sight.
item.dc:creator: Darryn King

item.title: Making the Dancing Lions for Lunar New York Celebrations
item.description: In a San Francisco garage, Corey Chan and his team create giant, spectacular lions that will lead the festivities.
item.dc:creator: Miya Lee and Jake Michaels

item.title: Milo Rau’s ‘Hate Radio,’ ‘Pelicot Trial’ and More Theater of the Real
item.description: Milo Rau’s examination of the infamous broadcast that preceded the Rwandan genocide is onstage now. Two other works, including “The Pelicot Trial,” arrive in March.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.category: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Aliona Kardash for The New York Times
item.media:description: With his stage work, the Swiss director-activist Milo Rau examines episodes of historical violence in an attempt to give audiences some measure of insight.

item.title: MIO: Memories in Orbit Evolves From Infuriating to Ingenious
item.description: MIO: Memories in Orbit is influenced by the platforming challenges of Hollow Knight.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Byrd

item.title: Noah Kahan, James Blake: 9 Songs We’re Talking About This Week
item.description: Sting joins the Argentine pop duo Ca7riel & Paco Amoroso on a track that recalls the Police, and Noah Kahan breaks into the Top 10 with his latest single.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles

item.title: A Winter Surfer at Rockaway Beach Questions His Dedication
item.description: But he begins to question his dedication to the sport on the way to Rockaway Beach in the depths of an icy midwinter. Is it worth it?
item.dc:creator: Haruka Aoki and Seldon Yuan

item.title: Tom Ellis on the 1960s Movie That Blew His Mind
item.description: “It made me feel all the feels as a kid that I didn’t know I had,” said the star of “Lucifer” and the new CBS series “CIA.”
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: How ‘Wonder Man’ Can Reshape the Marvel Franchise
item.description: Our culture critic Maya Phillips analyses Marvel‘s new show “Wonder Man” and looks at how it fits into the wider multiverse.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips, Edward Vega and Rafaela Balster

item.title: Ebo Taylor, Musical Innovator of Highlife and Afrobeat, Dies at 90
item.description: Borrowing from jazz and African rhythms, he forged a singular style that helped define music in his native Ghana — and West Africa — for a generation.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Ebo Taylor performing in 2011 in Wiltshire, England. In his final years, he began to receive international recognition.

item.title: Texas University Closes Exhibition With Anti-ICE Artwork
item.description: The exhibition at the University of North Texas by a Mexican-born artist included the language “Immigration and Cruelty Enforcement.”
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: Vicki Abt, Who Said TV Talk Shows Coarsened Society, Dies at 83
item.description: A Penn State sociology professor, she warned that hosts like Oprah Winfrey exploited vulnerable guests on television and sensationalized deviancy.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: In ‘Neighbors,’ the Golden Rule Is ‘Get Off My Lawn’
item.description: An HBO docuseries explores neighborly drama in a well-armed and hyper-online America. In an interview, the directors considered what it all means.
item.dc:creator: Austin Considine and Brian Karlsson
item.media:credit: Brian Karlsson for The New York Times

item.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
item.description: In this month’s picks, avengers of the toxic variety and princesses of the cosmic variety.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: ‘Tyler Perry’s Joe’s College Road Trip’ Review: Grandpa Knows Best
item.description: Madea only has a few minutes of screen time, but old man Joe has enough attitude to fuel this movie and then some.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.category: Tyler Perry's Joe's College Road Trip (Movie)

item.title: ‘Neighbors’ Review: One Battle After Another
item.description: A quirky HBO docuseries about small-scale feuds is the latest pop-culture portrait of a country full of tiny civil wars.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Good Luck, Have Fun, Don't Die (Movie)
Nirvanna the Band the Show the Movie (Movie)
Tyler Perry's Joe's College Road Trip (Movie)

item.title: The Times’s TV Editor Shares How He Recaps Episodes
item.description: How do we decide which television shows to write about, episode by episode? Our TV editor reveals his strategy.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Egner
item.media:description: Peter Claffey as Ser Duncan the Tall in the premiere of “A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms” on HBO Max.

item.title: A Family’s Memories and a Nation’s Struggles in ‘My Father’s Shadow’
item.description: The movie, created by two brothers, contrasts intimate impressions with a tense moment in Nigeria’s history.
item.dc:creator: Precious Adesina
item.media:credit: Ayesha Kazim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wale Davies, left, and Akinola Davies Jr. The brothers’ debut feature film, “My Father’s Shadow,” is a prize-winning coming-of-age saga.

item.title: Watch: Emerald Fennell Narrates a Clip of Margot Robbie in ‘Wuthering Heights’
item.description: The screenwriter and director Emerald Fennell narrates a sequence from her film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Jacob Elordi, Heathcliff and the Controversy Over ‘Wuthering Heights’
item.description: The character’s racial identity is at the heart of accusations that the film’s casting is “whitewashing.” But what does the original novel really say?
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: Christie’s to Auction 3 of Agnes Gund’s Art Jewels
item.description: A Rothko, a Twombly and a Surrealist box with a Medici princess by Joseph Cornell are estimated to sell for $145 million.
item.dc:creator: Julia Halperin

item.title: Trump Wants Smithsonian to Create a Different Official Portrait
item.description: The painted portrait from President Trump’s first term was completed more than four years ago, but never unveiled. Now he wants the National Portrait Gallery to commission a new one.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Michael Temchine for The New York Times

item.title: Stream These Documentaries on the Winter Olympics Going Back a Century
item.description: Commissioned by the International Olympic Committee, the movies provide a fascinating glimpse of history and the evolution of different sports.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Bud Greenspan's Torino 2006: Stories of Olympic Glory (Movie)

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director and screenwriter Emerald Fennell narrates a sequence from her film featuring Margot Robbie, Shazad Latif, Alison Oliver and Hong Chau.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: ‘The Daily Show’ Gives President Trump Yet Another Inaugural Award
item.description: Jordan Klepper congratulated the president, the sole nominee for “the Inaugural Award for Winning the Most Inaugural Awards.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Unknown’ Review: Sean Hayes Turns One Man Into a Mystery
item.description: The chameleonic actor takes on several characters in David Cale’s solo play about a writer in pursuit of his stalker. Or is it all in his mind?
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw
item.media:description: Sean Hayes in “The Unknown” at Studio Seaview in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: No Time for Goodbye
item.description: A sudden death rattles the doctors and nurses at the Pitt a little more than usual. Meanwhile, the patients keep steaming in.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: The bad first day back for Dr. Langdon (Patrick Ball) continued with the death of a beloved patient.

item.title: Greg Brown, Guitarist Who Wrote Cake’s Biggest Hit, Dies at 56
item.description: His song “The Distance,” released in 1996, became an anthem for the disaffected members of Generation X.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Mr. Brown in 1996. He left Cake after “Fashion Nugget,” partly over differences with the lead singer, John McCrea.

item.title: ‘Love Story’ Recreates a Tragic Romance
item.description: The series dramatizes the relationship between John F. Kennedy Jr. and Carolyn Bessette, who married in 1996 and died a few years later. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.category: Love Story: John F. Kennedy Jr. & Carolyn Bessette (TV Program)
